"It is moving the fire away from Chisholm and the Flatbush area, but who knows what is going to happen tomorrow."</p><p>About 30 people evacuated from farms north of Flatbush Friday had earlier been allowed to return to their homes, but remain on evacuation alert.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier The burned area is east of Highway 102 between Lantz and Milford.</p><p>Trees felled by last fall's hurricane Juan made the situation dangerous for firefighters. Hood said that as with many other woodlands in the area, 60 to 70 per cent of trees were on the ground.</p><p>"(It's) harder to fight. You've really got to watch your step while you're in there,'' he said. "You pretty well have to fight mainly from the air. If you get your men in there, you want to make sure you can get them out.''</p><p>At the height of the blaze, 100 firefighters were involved.</p><p>Hood said the helicopters were fortunate to be able to use water from a pond and a gypsum mine only minutes away.</p><p>(Halifax Chronicle-Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - Drought-like conditions fuelled 1,250 forest fires in northwestern Ontario this year: more than twice the region's annual average.</p><p>But those fires burned only about half the amount of forests destroyed in a typical year.</p><p>-BODY- The decrease in the area of forests destroyed was due in part to an increase in fire crews and new heavy water bomber airplanes, said Debbie MacLean, a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><p>The forest fire season in northwestern Ontario came to a close at the end of October. While that doesn't mean forest fires won't occur during the winter, the risk is "virtually non-existent'' with the arrival of cold weather.</p><p>It was the first year the ministry's natural fire policy came into effect in Quetico Park. Under the policy, fires caused by nature in the area that are contained and not influenced by so-called extreme conditions are monitored and allowed to burn out.</p><p>"The benefit is that, because it's a wilderness park, we let nature function freely,'' MacLean said, adding the ministry had actively suppressed fires in Quetico Park before the policy was approved.</p><p>MacLean said the "drought-like conditions'' hit areas including Thunder Bay, Ignace, Terrace Bay and Geraldton.</p><p>"Certainly it was a drier season than in normal years,'' said David Baggaley, a meteorologist with Environment Canada. Below-normal rain levels were recorded in June, July and August.</p><p>"We've certainly had some influence from El Nino,'' Baggaley said. "But it wasn't a record dry summer by any means.''</p><p>The worst forest fire season in the province was in 1989, when 2,430 fires destroyed 4,083 square kilometres. (Thunder Bay Chronicle-Journal)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Eds: Will be Writethru; INDEX: Health, Environment; HL:Alberta forest fire north of Edmonton continued to burn out of control Friday</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By John Cotter</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>EDMONTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>EDMONTON (CP) - Acrid smoke from a raging forest fire continued to drift across central Alberta Friday as crews fought to keep the blaze from consuming the hamlet of Chisholm.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Despite tinder dry conditions and out of control flames within three kilometres of the community, provincial fire officials had no plans to evacuate the area 200 kilometres north of Edmonton.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- "The conditions are very extreme,'' said Anna Kauffman, spokeswoman for the Resource Development department.</p><p>"But there has not been too much concern about evacuation at this point.''</p><p>However, officials said several families living north of the nearby community of Flatbush have left their homes as a precaution due to intense smoke in the area.</p><p>Farmer Elwin Whyte said the flames shot 30 metres feet in the air within a few kilometres from his wheat and barley operation on Thursday as the fire leaped from tree top to tree top.</p><p>Whyte sent his wife and younger children to safety but stayed behind with an older son to dig trenches and water down the outbuildings.</p><p>He said the situation was "pretty scary.''</p><p>"I was worried. You get quite excited.''</p><p>The 40-square-kilometre fire broke out Wednesday near the CNR rail line, but the cause of the blaze is still under investigation, Kauffman said.</p><p>The area is mainly wooded hills and farmland. Drought conditions and moderate winds have made it difficult to contain the fire, she said.</p><p>Hundreds of gas wells are in the area, but they were shut down as a precaution before the flames got too close.</p><p>More than 160 firefighters, including helicopters, are battling the blaze.</p><p>A total of 17 fires were burning in the province Friday.</p><p>The dry conditions prompted the province to extend a ban on open fires from a line between Peace River and Lac la Biche in northern Alberta to points just above the U.S. border.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Four lumber and pulp mills were also evacuated.</p><p>As late as Sunday afternoon, the so-called Chisholm fire was thought to be largely under control.</p><p>But under near-perfect conditions of dry fuel, the fire jumped the Athabasca River and more than doubled in size overnight. Winds gusting to 70 kilometres an hour pushed the fire like an arrow directly toward Slave Lake at the rate of six kilometres an hour.</p><p>Fire crews from Alberta, Ontario, British Columbia and Manitoba were using 17 helicopters, 24 bulldozers and 300 men to battle the blaze, which has already burned an area three times the size of the city of Edmonton.</p><p>"(The fire) is an animal. It's living and breathing and eating all the fuels in the forest," firefighter Mike Durocher of Ontario told CFRN-TV.</p><p>He said this is one of the worse blazes he's ever seen in his 11 years on the job.</p><p>"Because of these drought conditions, it's going very fast."</p><p>By yesterday afternoon, the fire was only 20 kilometres from town, leaving fire officials praying for a break in the weather.</p><p>"There are some things we can do to steer the fire," said fire behaviour officer Cordy Tymstra. "But when the fire is rolling like a locomotive, there is very little any fire suppression agency can do."</p><p>Slave Lake Mayor Gerry Allarie said the fire was already making its presence felt.</p><p>"It's very black here," he said. "There's lots of ash coming down on the town and the wind isn't doing us any favours."</p><p>The municipality was responsible for making the decision to evacuate.</p><p>Highways 2 and 2A were closed for 50 kilometres east of Slave Lake, RCMP Cpl. Peter Quilty said.</p><p>"They're anticipating the fire to jump Highway 2 somewhere in the Mitsou area (15 kilometres east of town). They can't give an exact location. That's why they closed the highway.</p><p>"It's like night-time here almost."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata NORTH BAY - UPDATE (Tuesday, July 31, 10:45 p.m.): By the evening of July 31 there were 41 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 13 are not yet under control and 28 are either being held, under control or being observed.

Within the Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services reports North Bay 72 now cover 27,285.7 hectares and is not under control. There were a few smokes and hot spots observed again Tuesday, July 31.

Values protection equipment remains in place for camps and cottages located on Mendelssohn Lake and Skull Lake. There is over 12 kilometres of dozer guard along the northwest head of the fire, which was created using multiple pieces of heavy equipment.

There are over 200 front line forest fire fighters assigned to this fire.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (Monday, July 30, 11:52 p.m.): By the evening of July 30 there were 41 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 26 are either being held, under control or being observed.

Within the Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services reports North Bay 72 is not under control, at approximately 27,275 hectares. There were a few smokes and hot spots observed Monday, July 30.

Infrared scanning continues to happen when weather conditions cooperate. Multiple pieces of heavy equipment continue to build dozer guard along the fire's edge.

UPDATE (Sunday, July 29, 11:45 p.m.): By the evening of July 29 there were 39 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 14 are not yet under control, 25 are either being held, under control or being observed.

Shortly after 3 p.m. on Sunday, July 29, the ministry remapped the cluster to 27,275, slightly smaller than what was reported earlier Sunday morning.

#NorthBay 72 in the Lady Evelyn fire cluster is remapped to 27,275 hectares. Visit our https://t.co/XPnoZFTS24 page for updated information. #forestfires #ontario pic.twitter.com/PawIhPaTgn

- ONForestFires (@ONforestfires) July 29, 2018

River Valley Fire Cluster

This cluster includes North Bay 25, 42 and 62. North Bay 25 is at 176 hectares in Sturgeon River Provincial Park. North Bay 42, north of Red Cedar Lake, is being held at 350 hectares. North Bay 62 is southwest of Hand Lake and is under control at 2,500 hectares. There are 129 people working on these fires including fire fighters from Ontario, British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Nova Scotia and Mexico.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster

North Bay 72 was remapped at 27,275 hectares - a decrease of 304 hectares. By flying at a low level when there is very little smoke, staff are better able to see the edge of the fire and map it more accurately. This fire is still listed at not under control and may become more active over the next few days as the areas starts to dry out from recent precipitation. Another group of Mexican firefighters has arrived at this fire and will be placed on the fireline in the morning.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (8:46 a.m. Sunday, July 29) By the evening of Saturday, July 28 there were 39 active forest fires across the northeast. of these, 12 are not yet under control, 27 are either being held, under control or are being observed.

There were no new forest fires discovered on July 28.

River Valley Fire Cluster

Crews made solid progress on all fires today. North Bay 62 was deemed under control on the morning of Saturday, July 28. Crews worked on the north side of North Bay 42 and made good progress. NOR 025 is also under control.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster

North Bay Fire 072 remains at 27,579 hectares and is listed as not under control. A little bit of smoke was observed on the fire later in the afternoon of Saturday, July 28 and the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry anticipates that will increase over the next few days as the weather returns to seasonal values and temperatures reach the mid to high 20s. There are 11 helicopters assigned to this cluster.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (9 a.m., Saturday, July 28) By the evening of Friday, July 27 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports there were 43 forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 13 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held under control or being observed.

There was one new fire confirmed, North Bay 119, located eight kilometres southwest of Lachford was 0.1 hectares and is already out.

A total of three fires were extinguished today.

River Valley Fire Cluster

This cluster includes two fires - North Bay 62 and North Bay 42. Both of these fires are being held. North Bay 25 is being monitored to the west of the cluster, which is now under control at 200 hectares.

There are 135 people working on these fires including firefighters from Ontario, Alberta, British Columbia, Nova Scotia, Saskatchewan and Mexico.

Crews made progress on all fires in the cluster today working on the southside of North Bay 42 and continued to work the perimeter on North Bay 62 while other crews continued to recover equipment from the fire.

Some smoke was visible on North Bay 25 while crews worked to extinguish hot spots.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster

The North Bay 72 fire remains at 27,579 hectares and is not yet under control. The fire was scanned from the air in the early morning of July 27. Infrared scanning identifies areas that are holding heat so fire rangers can walk the fire and extinguish hot spots.

The Incident Management Team assigned to this cluster continues to observe North Bay fires 18, 19, 46, 59, and 61. These fires will also be scanned using infrared technology in the coming days.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26): By the evening of Thursday, July 26, there were 45 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed.

River Valley Fire Cluster

The River Valley Fire Cluster includes two fires: North Bay 62 and North Bay 42. Both fires are now being held, meaning that the fires are not expected to spread under current conditions. The ministry is continuing to monitor North Bay 25 to the west of the cluster, which is now under control.

There are 154 people working on these fires including firefighters from Ontario, British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Nova Scotia and Mexico.

Crews took advantage of the cooler, dry day to make solid progress on all fires. On North Bay 42, crews continued to secure the perimeter on the north side as well as working on hot spots on the west side. For North Bay 62, crews continued to work the perimeter of the fire while some crews began to recover equipment from the fire.

Crews completed removal of sprinkler protection from all structures.

Temagami Fire Cluster:

Fire activity has proven more manageable on fires in the Temagami cluster with all active fires in this cluster now classified as either being held or under control.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster:

North Bay 72 remains at 27,579 hectares and is listed as not under control. However, the overcast skies and wet weather of late has allowed firefighters to consolidate hose lines along the perimeter. While there is much work still to be done, progress is being made daily.

Front line staff continue to work with heavy equipment operators to establish dozer guards in areas where this type of suppression is suitable. This goes a long way to secure the perimeter of the fire.

The Incident Management Team continues to observe North Bay 18, 19, 46, 59 and 61. While these fires have been quiet, they are not considered out.

Currently there are 10 helicopters assigned to this cluster. Transitioning of staff is ongoing as personnel depart for their home locations and new staff arrive. Crews arrived from northwestern Ontario today and more are expected from Saskatchewan tomorrow.

The ministry continues to have firefighters from British Columbia, Alberta, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, Northwest Territories and Mexico work on this cluster.

Restricted Fire Zone expanded

Restricted fire zone has been expanded to additional parts of the northeast fire region (southern region).

Due to the extreme fire hazard, several recent periods of heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone. This expansion of the current Restricted Fire Zone will be in effect as of 12:01 a.m. on Tuesday, July 24, and remain in place until further notice.

The expanded Restricted Fire Zone now includes Zones 24, 25 and 26 which would include areas south of the French River, including Parry Sound, from Georgian Bay east to the Quebec border, including Algonquin Provincial Park and from Renfrew north to Mattawa.

To date, the current Restricted Fire Zone covers Zones 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 24, 25 and 26 and restrictions will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for an outline of the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris, is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

Ontario is receiving support from across Canada, the United States and Mexico to assist with the fire situation. Additional personnel and equipment are expected to arrive in the province in the coming days, including ignition specialists from Parks Canada.

Travel restrictions

Travel restrictions remain in place for parts of North Bay, Kirkland Lake, Sudbury and Pembroke and districts due to forest fires.

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of North Bay, Kirkland Lake and Sudbury Districts where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity.

The Order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions.

This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

All travel and use of the following roads are prohibited: McLaren's Road, Gibbons Road, Baie-Jeanne Road, South Pardo Road, Beauty Lake Road, St. Joseph's Road, George Gordon and Iron Lake Road, Cooke Lake Road, Liskeard Lumber Road, Klock Lake Road, Crane Lake Road, Roadhouse Tower Road, Indian Bay Road, Mountain Lake Road, and Goulard Road starting at Lower Goose Falls.

All modes of travel/access into Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater, Obabika River, Makobe-Grays River, Solace and Sturgeon River Provincial Parks, and all Crown lands is prohibited.

Use of the Red Squirrel Lake Road beyond the Barmac Gate is prohibited.

All use and occupation of Crown land on or within 500 metres of all described closed roads is prohibited.

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for non-recreational purposes, please call North Bay District at 705-475-5546 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) or Kirkland Lake District at 705-568-3240 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) to request a travel authorization permit. For requesting access to Red Squirrel Lake Road, please call North Bay District. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

See the restricted travel and access areas on this PDF map (Note: this map gets updated regularly).

Smoke concerns

Smoke from large fires across the region will be visible until fire activity is reduced and weather patterns change.

Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services is reminding the public that if they do see flames or smoke, please report it, and stay away from the area in the interest of public safety.

If you have questions or concerns about smoke and your health, please contact Tele Health Ontario at 1-866-797-0000.

To report a forest fire located north of the French and Mattawa rivers, please dial 310-FIRE (3473)

To report a forest fire located south of the French or Mattawa rivers, please dial 911.

Follow Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry on Twitter @ONForestFires

For up to date information on current fires in the province or to check the forest fire hazard in your area, visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Pinnacle Renewable (PL.TO) -- an industrial wood pellet manufacturer and distributor and the third largest producer in the world that saw its stock lose near 3% yesterday -- said late Wednesday that it is "closely monitoring" the wildfires near its facilities and will give updates if the high level of forest fires in British Columbia hurts its operations.

Currently, the company said that none of its facilities are under immediate threat of encroachment from wildfires. Pinnacle said that if it needs to evacuate or temporarily close a facility due to forest fire encroachment, it is experienced in managing its network of facilities to ensure customer shipments.

Vaughan Bassett, Senior VP, Sales and Logistics, said: "We are adept at managing our network of facilities to adjust for potential temporary operational disruptions. We had to close our Williams Lake production facility for 24 days last year during July and August due to a forest fire and no customer shipments were missed. Our network of facilities was able to absorb this temporary closure and make up the production elsewhere."

Shares on Wednesday decreased 2.9% to $15.92 apiece in a 52-week range of $10.50 - 16.70.

STORNOWAY DIAMOND CORP ("SWY,SWY.DB.U-T;SWYDF-0") - Temporary Suspension of Renard Mine Operations Due to Forest Fire

Stornoway Diamond Corporation (the "Corporation" or "Stornoway") announces that mine operations at the Renard Diamond Mine have been temporarily suspended due to a local forest fire. As at 06.30h EST on Monday, the fire was located 12.6 kilometres south of the Renard Mine, but just 3.6 kilometres south of the Clarence and Abel Swallow Airport and within 0.1 kilometre of the mine's access road. It covers an area of 18 kilometres by 6 kilometres and is being fanned by northerly winds.

While mine facilities are in no immediate danger, the location of the fire means that access to the site is affected. For precautionary reasons, non-essential staff are being evacuated and road deliveries suspended until normal safe working conditions can be re-established.

Rain and a change in wind direction is forecast in the next 24 to 48 hours. Stornoway will provide further updates as they become available.

About the Renard Diamond Mine

The Renard Diamond Mine is Quebec's first producing diamond mine and Canada's sixth. It is located approximately 250 km north of the Cree community of Mistissini and 350 km north of Chibougamau in the James Bay region of north-central Quebec. Construction on the project commenced on July 10, 2014, and commercial production was declared on January 1, 2017. Average annual diamond production is forecast at 1.8 million carats per annum over the first 10 years of mining. Readers are referred to the technical report dated January 11, 2016, in respect of the September 2015 Mineral Resource estimate, and the technical report dated March 30, 2016, in respect of the March 2016 Updated Mine Plan and Mineral Reserve Estimate for further details and assumptions relating to the project.

About Stornoway Diamond Corporation

Stornoway is a leading Canadian diamond exploration and development company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange under the symbol SWY and headquartered in Montreal. Our flagship asset is the 100% owned Renard Diamond Project, Quebec's first diamond mine. Stornoway is a growth oriented company with a world-class asset, in one of the world's best mining jurisdictions, in one of the world's great mining businesses.

The evacuation alert affects residents of Chute Lake, Okaview, Kettle Valley and Uplands.</p><p>The alert is in addition to an evacuation order that affected about 50 homes last night.</p><p>The forest service says the fire is burning in steep and rough terrain, which is limiting access by ground crews and heavy equipment.</p><p>Gusting winds kicked up mini tornadoes early yesterday that shot "fire storms" through containment lines and across highways, forcing firefighters to retreat.</p><p>"The direction of the winds last night was erratic," said Kevin Matuga, fire information officer for the B.C. Forest Service.</p><p>"Fire crews were reporting what we refer to as dust devils or localized, small tornadoes that were causing the fire to do things we've never seen before, making it impossible to forecast the fire and making the situation very difficult."</p><p>In order to stay safe, firefighters could do nothing but stand back and watch, he said.</p><p>As many of the fires grew overnight by hundreds of hectares, the province responded to the escalating risk to communities.</p><p>About 1,500 people remained out of their homes yesterday under evacuation orders in areas around Kamloops and Kelowna.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier At least one home was destroyed.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Floyd Thompson, the settlement's chairman, said late Wednesday flames were still dancing through the crowns of trees and firefighters would be continuing their efforts throughout the night.</p><p>Ambulance personnel had to give many people oxygen after heavy smoke descended on the settlement.</p><p>"There are a number of fires," Thompson said in a phone interview. "It's creating a lot of smoke. Visibility was down to zero."</p><p>Two busloads of senior citizens and children were voluntarily evacuated to nearby Vilna in the afternoon. Plans were in place to evacuate more of the 1,000 residents if the fire continued to threaten populated areas.</p><p>"From all sides you can see nothing but red sky and flames," resident Kendra Tocher said. "It's pretty scary. If you looked at it from the air, the fire would look like a broken circle around the settlement."</p><p>She said firefighters from neighboring reserves of Goodfish Lake and Beaver Lake built a fire line around the Kikino school in the afternoon after the blazes came within metres of the structure. "The fire was that close. It was right in the village."</p><p>Buildings in a soon-to-be-completed resort area beside a lake on the settlement were spared but the forest surrounding it was destroyed.</p><p>Dry weather and high winds combined to cause numerous ground fires to flare and spread quickly to trees, Thompson said, adding he was uncertain how large the fire was.</p><p>More problems were expected Thursday as the unseasonably warm temperatures and high winds were expected to continue, Thompson said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata It's stopped within three kilometres of both."</p><p>Carson said some small fires, known as hot spots, were found outside the fire lines closer to one of the subdivisions, but firefighters quickly contained them.</p><p>The temperature was rising late Friday afternoon and there was a threat of thunderstorms, he said.</p><p>Thunderstorms hit the area Friday, bringing lightning and showers, but neither had an impact on the blaze, which stunned residents with its power.</p><p>"It sounded like a freight train," Robert Suits said of the fire that threatened his Echo Valley subdivision Thursday night.</p><p>The fire started Thursday afternoon and quickly spread to cover an area equal to about 1,700 football fields about seven kilometres from downtown Whitehorse. Cause of the blaze was not known.</p><p>Echo Valley resident Gordon Lowry said it was a spectacular sight.</p><p>"The whole top of the mountain was on fire," said Lowry. "The wind blew the smoke away for a split second and you could see the whole top of the mountain all lit up."</p><p>None of the homes in the subdivision had been touched by the fire.</p><p>"This is a high-intensity fire in a high-priority area," said Al Beaver at the forest fire control centre.</p><p>Residents of the Crestview subdivision, about three kilometres from downtown, were on evacuation standby, officials said.</p><p>Crestview melds into the outskirts of Whitehorse while there is more of a gap, as much as a few kilometres, between the Echo Valley subdivision and the city.</p><p>Whitehorse is located at the navigational head of the Yukon River, about 100 kilometres north of the B.C. border. It is one of Canada's largest cities, in area, at 675 square kilometres.</p><p>Many of the Yukon capital's older buildings are constructed of wood, while the newer ones are made of steel and concrete, said Living.</p><p>Sixty firefighter reinforcements came from British Columbia, bringing to 150 the number of firefighters.</p><p>Eight air tankers, two helicopters and three other plans monitored the fire and plotted courses for the air tankers.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>A 1,500-hectare forest fire raged near two Whitehorse suburbs in the (CP) _ More than 80 firefighters were battling a large forest fire Thursday that doubled in size overnight east of this Okanagan community.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The blaze covered about 1,000 hectares and emergency crews were determining whether they should bring in additional help, Kevin Matuga, a fire information officer, said Thursday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"The fire continued to spread overnight and it is continuing to spread today,'' he said. "We expected that, given how dry it is in the area and the kind of weather conditions we are seeing.''</p><p>The community of Osoyoos, located three kilometres west of the burning area, is not threatened, he said.</p><p>But the blaze, which is more than twice the size of Stanley Park in Vancouver, has forced officials to put 32 households in a rural area known as Anarchist Mountain on evacuation alert.</p><p>Some people have voluntarily left their homes and two structures were destroyed in the fire, but Matuga couldn't confirm the building type.</p><p>"In this area there are homes and outbuildings,'' he said, adding that crews were able to save numerous homes Wednesday, although some did receive exterior damage.</p><p>Weather in the region is forecast to remain hot and dry throughout the weekend.</p><p>The cause of the fire is still unknown.</p><p>Two water bombers and helicopters were also being used to fight the fire.</p><p>Highway 3 near Anarchist Mountain was closed Wednesday afternoon due to poor visibility from smoke.</p><p>It was reopened Thursday at about noon, but officials warned it could be closed again if conditions worsened.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Difficult terrain with steep rock faces slowed down the fight to bring it under control.</p><p>Fire continued to rip through tinder-dry trees and brush Thursday night. Flames licked up the sides of trees, which sometimes exploded from the heat, Ms Stewart said.</p><p>The blaze jumped a guard on its south side Thursday afternoon and raced further up the wooded hillside above Ellis Creek canyon.</p><p>Three more water bombers, including a large DC-6, were brought in from Castlegar, B.C., to help battle the blaze, bringing the air fleet to five LILLOOET, B.C. _ High winds have fanned the flames of a growing forest fire in B.C.'s Interior.

Elise Riedlinger, fire information officer for the Kamloops Fire Centre, said 3,500 hectares of forest were being consumed Saturday by the Tyaughton Lake fire west of Lillooet.

Since Friday, the blaze had grown by 1,500 hectares.

The fire season is off to a raging start compared to last year at this time when only a total of 118 hectares were burning in several area fires, Riedlinger said.

''We're starting out with very dry conditions,'' she said, adding more high winds were expected later Saturday.

Riedlinger said 28 more firefighters and two extra helicopters joined the effort on Saturday, for a total of 165 firefighters and 11 helicopters that are battling the blaze.

But she says more high winds are expected. And the rain that was forecast for Tuesday will apparently not be showing up to help out.

''It was looking like slight precipitation for Tuesday but now it's looking like hardly any significant precipitation for the coming week or so,'' Riedlinger said.

Only about 15 per cent of the fire has been contained so far.

The Kamloops Fire Centre is trying to protect buildings near the fire after an evacuation order was issued Friday.

The blaze is believed to have been caused by someone and is under investigation.

Jillian Chimko, a fire information officer with the Prince George Fire Centre, said 13,400 hectares are burning at the junction of the Liard and Smith rivers in northern B.C.

She said the 60 people who were ordered to leave their homes Thursday were allowed to return Friday after the growth of the fire slowed down.

urn:contentItem:5CWD-3NC1-DY91-K1J1-00000-00Slave Lake residue may pose health risk2011-06-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:29ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A22Slave Lake residue may pose health riskToxins in forest-fire ash beyond healthy levels for soil, scientists assertBob Weber The Canadian PressEDMONTON

Scientists are questioning the Alberta government's assurances that residue from the Slave Lake forest fire doesn't pose a health risk.

"I don't think that you can brush it off and say everything that's here is not an issue," said Anne Naeth at the University of Alberta.

"Obviously, when you're finding dioxins and furans and other potential carcinogenic compounds, then that is an issue."

Late Thursday, the province released results of tests done on the ash and residue left behind after a forest fire destroyed more than 400 homes and businesses and forced 7,000 people to flee.

"Test results of ash samples taken from the burned-out areas of Slave Lake show that current levels of contaminants present in ash do not present risk to human health," said the government's news release.

But a look at the figures reveals that levels of several highly toxic compounds are at levels many times higher than those recommended by provincial guidelines for residential soils.

Lead, a powerful neurotoxin especially dangerous to children, is at three times the recommended levels. Copper is 23 times over the limit. Zinc is 22 times higher than it should be.

Dioxins and furans, some of which are highly potent carcinogens, are anywhere from 13 to 52 times the guideline levels.

Several types of carcinogenic hydrocarbons, for which no safe level is listed, were also found. As well, the ash was so alkaline it would be caustic if mixed with water.

"There's some wildly high numbers," said independent ecologist Kevin Timoney.

Alberta Environment says that the soil guidelines aren't appropriate for the ash tests. Ash isn't soil and shouldn't be held to that standard, said spokeswoman Jessica Potter.

She said the department will monitor the contaminant levels for six months and then compare the results to soil guidelines.

But Naeth, an expert in land reclamation, wonders if that distinction should matter to Slave Lake residents trying to return to their normal lives.

"This is not soil. This is a contaminant on the surface of the soil," she acknowledged. "But you still have to take into account that it's there.

"In reality, people are going to be acting the same way they would with soil. They're going to walk on it. They're going to eventually dig it. Some of it's eventually going to blow away.

"If this is going to be considered soil six months down the road when you do your next follow-up, why is it not considered soil right now?"

Despite the no-risk assurances from the government, Alberta Health is advising people to be careful on burned-out sites. The department says people should wear - "at minimum" - head-to-toe clothing complete with breathing masks.

River Valley Fire Cluster

North Bay 62 is southwest of Hand Lake and is under control at 2,500 hectares. By flying at a low level when there is very little smoke, staff are better able to see the edge of the fire and map it more accurately. This fire is still listed at not under control and may become more active over the next few days as the areas starts to dry out from recent precipitation. Another group of Mexican firefighters has arrived at this fire and will be placed on the fireline in the morning.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (8:46 a.m. Sunday, July 29) By the evening of Saturday, July 28 there were 39 active forest fires across the northeast. of these, 12 are not yet under control, 27 are either being held, under control or are being observed.

There were no new forest fires discovered on July 28.

River Valley Fire Cluster

Crews made solid progress on all fires today. North Bay 62 was deemed under control on the morning of Saturday, July 28. Crews worked on the north side of North Bay 42 and made good progress. NOR 025 is also under control.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster

North Bay Fire 072 remains at 27,579 hectares and is listed as not under control. A little bit of smoke was observed on the fire later in the afternoon of Saturday, July 28 and the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry anticipates that will increase over the next few days as the weather returns to seasonal values and temperatures reach the mid to high 20s. NORTH BAY - UPDATE (9 a.m., Saturday, July 28) By the evening of Friday, July 27 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports there were 43 forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 13 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held under control or being observed.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26): By the evening of Thursday, July 26, there were 45 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed.

River Valley Fire Cluster

The River Valley Fire Cluster includes two fires: North Bay 62 and North Bay 42. Both fires are now being held, meaning that the fires are not expected to spread under current conditions. The ministry is continuing to monitor North Bay 25 to the west of the cluster, which is now under control.

There are 154 people working on these fires including firefighters from Ontario, British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Nova Scotia and Mexico.

Crews took advantage of the cooler, dry day to make solid progress on all fires. On North Bay 42, crews continued to secure the perimeter on the north side as well as working on hot spots on the west side. For North Bay 62, crews continued to work the perimeter of the fire while some crews began to recover equipment from the fire.

Crews completed removal of sprinkler protection from all structures.

Temagami Fire Cluster:

Fire activity has proven more manageable on fires in the Temagami cluster with all active fires in this cluster now classified as either being held or under control.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster:

North Bay 72 remains at 27,579 hectares and is listed as not under control. However, the overcast skies and wet weather of late has allowed firefighters to consolidate hose lines along the perimeter. While there is much work still to be done, progress is being made daily.

Front line staff continue to work with heavy equipment operators to establish dozer guards in areas where this type of suppression is suitable. This goes a long way to secure the perimeter of the fire.

The Incident Management Team continues to observe North Bay 18, 19, 46, 59 and 61. While these fires have been quiet, they are not considered out.

Currently there are 10 helicopters assigned to this cluster. Transitioning of staff is ongoing as personnel depart for their home locations and new staff arrive. Crews arrived from northwestern Ontario today and more are expected from Saskatchewan tomorrow.

The ministry continues to have firefighters from British Columbia, Alberta, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, Northwest Territories and Mexico work on this cluster.

Restricted Fire Zone expanded

Restricted fire zone has been expanded to additional parts of the northeast fire region (southern region).

Due to the extreme fire hazard, several recent periods of heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone. This expansion of the current Restricted Fire Zone will be in effect as of 12:01 a.m. on Tuesday, July 24, and remain in place until further notice.

The expanded Restricted Fire Zone now includes Zones 24, 25 and 26 which would include areas south of the French River, including Parry Sound, from Georgian Bay east to the Quebec border, including Algonquin Provincial Park and from Renfrew north to Mattawa.

To date, the current Restricted Fire Zone covers Zones 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 24, 25 and 26 and restrictions will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for an outline of the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris, is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

Ontario is receiving support from across Canada, the United States and Mexico to assist with the fire situation. Additional personnel and equipment are expected to arrive in the province in the coming days, including ignition specialists from Parks Canada.

Travel restrictions

Travel restrictions remain in place for parts of North Bay, Kirkland Lake, Sudbury and Pembroke and districts due to forest fires.

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of North Bay, Kirkland Lake and Sudbury Districts where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity.

The Order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions.

This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

All travel and use of the following roads are prohibited: McLaren's Road, Gibbons Road, Baie-Jeanne Road, South Pardo Road, Beauty Lake Road, St. Joseph's Road, George Gordon and Iron Lake Road, Cooke Lake Road, Liskeard Lumber Road, Klock Lake Road, Crane Lake Road, Roadhouse Tower Road, Indian Bay Road, Mountain Lake Road, and Goulard Road starting at Lower Goose Falls.

All modes of travel/access into Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater, Obabika River, Makobe-Grays River, Solace and Sturgeon River Provincial Parks, and all Crown lands is prohibited.

Use of the Red Squirrel Lake Road beyond the Barmac Gate is prohibited.

All use and occupation of Crown land on or within 500 metres of all described closed roads is prohibited.

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for non-recreational purposes, please call North Bay District at 705-475-5546 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) or Kirkland Lake District at 705-568-3240 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) to request a travel authorization permit. For requesting access to Red Squirrel Lake Road, please call North Bay District. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

See the restricted travel and access areas on this PDF map (Note: this map gets updated regularly).

Smoke concerns

Smoke from large fires across the region will be visible until fire activity is reduced and weather patterns change.

Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services is reminding the public that if they do see flames or smoke, please report it, and stay away from the area in the interest of public safety.

If you have questions or concerns about smoke and your health, please contact Tele Health Ontario at 1-866-797-0000.

To report a forest fire located north of the French and Mattawa rivers, please dial 310-FIRE (3473)

To report a forest fire located south of the French or Mattawa rivers, please dial 911.

Follow Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry on Twitter @ONForestFires

B6Forest fire survivors ran to oceanFind themselves struggling to stay afloat for hours, drifting from land before lucky rescueDerek Gatopoulos The Associated PressThe Associated Press

(CP) _ A sudden windshift Wednesday night lessened the threat of a forest fire that had forced the evacuation of hundreds of homes from two Labrador communities hours earlier.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Winds gusting to 70 kilometres an hour drove the out-of-control fire across 150 hectares of land and on a beeline for the communities of North West River and Sheshatshiu.</p><p>Then, around 6 p.m., the wind turned and dropped off, officials said.</p><p>The change gave water bombers, which had been unable to fly in the stiff wind, the chance to swoop in and start tackling the blaze.</p><p> We managed to cut it off just before it reached the major standing timber in the area of the community,'' said Gerald Fleming, a forest duty officer.</p><p>Earlier, RCMP officers went door-to-door to evacuate 1,500 residents from the two remote communities, fearing the blaze would reach the houses. The fire came within 13 kilometres of the communities, said Fleming.</p><p>Two water bombers and helicopters continued to battle the fire until dark.</p><p> It relieves, at least immediately, the threat to the community,'' Fleming said.</p><p>Aircraft were to tackle the blaze again Thursday morning, with additional help from 32 firefighters on the ground.</p><p>The communities were to remain evacuated until officials could further evaluate the fire.</p><p>Wind conditions were expected to continue to be favourable for firefighters Thursday, Fleming said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20020703CPCPG2382</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2002</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:466N-KK80-01G6-94WC-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="230"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2002 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="03" month="07" year="2002"><dateText>July 3, 2002 Wednesday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>ENVIRONMENT; A20</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire threatens reserve</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>From Canadian Press</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>A huge forest fire north of Red Lake in northwestern Ontario continued to burn out of control today while another major fire farther north threatened an isolated Indian reserve.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A forest fire in Quebec, meanwhile, forced the evacuation yesterday of 850 people in the Indian village of Waswanapi, about 80 kilometres (50 miles) north of Montreal.</p><p nitf:lede="true">In Ontario's northwest, a record hot spell with temperatures as high as 35C (95F) and shifting winds have stymied firefighters' efforts to keep the damage from the 27 fires burning in the province to a minimum.</p><p>Six of the fires - three in northwestern Ontario and three in the eastern region of Cochrane, Hearst and Timmins - remain out of control.</p><p>The 2,500 residents of Red Lake, a mining and tourist base 170 kilometres (105 miles) northeast of Kenora, were not expected to be threatened by the fires, although they have awakened to a smoky haze for the past few days.</p><p>In the far north near Sandy Lake, Red 14, which has burned 27,000 hectares (66,716 acres), was threatening the North Spirit Lake Indian reservation of 284 people, about 170 kilometres (106 miles) northeast of Red Lake.</p><p>About 200 residents of the reserve have been told to be ready if it becomes necessary to ferry them across the lake to a fishing lodge, Ron Running, a spokesman with the natural resources ministry, said today.</p><p>Running said crews were constructing a fire wall to protect the village from Red 14, which is moving towards the village. If the efforts are unsuccessful, the band will be moved.</p><p>Officials don't expect the hot, dry conditions to improve until at least the weekend, when cooler weather and possibly thunderstorms are expected in all areas except Red 7, which has burned 17,500 hectares (43,241 acres), much of it prime timber on Crown land. For the past two days, northwestern Ontario has been the hottest spot in Canada, and no rain has fallen for almost two weeks.</p><p>Running said Red 7, about 70 kilometres (43 miles) from the Manitoba border, rapidly grew east yesterday, aided by gentle winds. Gusts later picked up and the fire jumped a section of fireline crews had burned to contain it.</p><p>"It got into some very good jackpine timber," Running said.</p><p>The ministry has warned about 30 to 40 nearby bushcutters to move their equipment and personnel to safer ground. It has also issued an emergency area order in the Red Lake vicinity, which means people must evacuate if the ministry decides it is necessary.</p><p>Fire crews are watching but not fighting the two other northwestern fires, Running said. Red 5 has blackened 32,000 hectares (79,071 acres) most of it less-valuable bush.</p><p>Three fires out of control in northeastern Ontario are much smaller and are expected to be manageable shortly, Running said.</p><p>A total of 303 five-man fire crews are working or on standby, he said.</p><p>A high to extreme fire hazard remains in effect across the area, and no open campfires are permitted anywhere in the North.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Map Ontario Manitoba "I've been told they could be put out very easily. They've already destroyed property up in the area. They're endangering a number of fishing camps, outfitting camps, destroying part of our tourism area.''</p><p>Provincial spokesman Steve Roberts said that outside of the commercial timber areas, the department has an "observation zone'' where fire is allowed to play a more natural role.</p><p>"We have identified all of the values at risk including cabins, outfitters, mines, drilling sites, even for instance, critical caribou winter range habitat,'' Roberts said.</p><p>"And when we have a fire out there, we monitor the fire and intervene to protect those risks, not necessarily proceed to extinguish every single fire.''</p><p>In the case of Howe's Lake, firefighters were trying to protect cabins in the area, he said.</p><p>But when the fire expanded, crews were unable to enter the area. Three of 17 cabins were destroyed.</p><p>Roberts said that if more fires had been allowed to take their course in the past, there would not have been as much over-mature timber building up fuel which feeds the intensity of the fires.</p><p>(Saskatoon StarPhoenix)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - Ontario's largest forest fire is looming northeast of here like a giant shadow, reaching 250 square kilometres and fast approaching the size of the city itself.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It's basically about the size of Thunder Bay,'' Dave Jackson, a provincial fire information officer, said Wednesday.</p><p>The fire is burning close to the remote village of Gull Bay First Nation, about 150 kilometres north of Thunder Bay, on Lake Nipigon.</p><p>About 50 people were evacuated from the village earlier this week but most had returned to their homes as the threat to their community decreased.</p><p>Jackson said the fire was burning back on itself after the wind changed direction.</p><p>A total of 148 firefighters and 40 Natural Resources workers are fighting the flames, using water bombers and helicopters.</p><p>Showers are forecast for today.</p><p>"It's a good opportunity to make some headway and the rain they are calling for should help us further,'' Jackson said Wednesday.</p><p>He said despite extremely dry conditions there have been relatively few fires in Northwestern Ontario.</p><p>"We don't know what the future holds. If we had lightning go through, we'd have our hands full.''</p><p>So far, damage from the fire has been restricted to several kilometres of timber harvesting limits licensed to Avenor and Abitibi-Consolidated.</p><p>About 10 small forest fires were reported across the region Wednesday. Two small fires were put out Tuesday near Thunder Bay, one 20 kilometres south of Kakabeka Falls and one 20 kilometres north of Shabaqua.</p><p>The second biggest active fire in the region is a blaze 15 kilometres east of Dryden, measuring about 10 city blocks.</p><p>An unusually dry April has prompted the Natural Resources Ministry to issue a fire ban in the area from Manitoba's border to the western shores of Lake Nipigon, including Thunder Bay. All fires, including campfires, are banned. (Thunder Bay Chronicle-Journal)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - Residents of two ranches that had been evacuated from the path of an advancing fire near the small Okanagan town of Tulameen were allowed to return Saturday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Lighter winds aided firefighters in battling the blaze, the second-largest in the province so far this summer.</p><p>-BODY- "These folks have been able to return home, but they're still on evacuation alert,'' said fire information officer Wendy Stewart of the 12 people forced to leave the Bar-O-Bar and Thynne Lake ranches.</p><p>Another 650 residents of the Otter Valley and Tulameen, northwest of Princeton, also remained on evacuation alert. They can be asked to leave their homes with 10 minutes' notice.</p><p>The fire is burning between two and eight kilometres from populated areas.</p><p>Using more sophisticated mapping technology, the B.C. Forest Service now estimates the fire has blackened 6,700 hectares of forest.</p><p>A fire that forced the evacuation of hundreds from Salmon Arm last month charred 6,200 hectares.</p><p>Weather conditions allowed firefighters to build fire guards around the fire perimeter, said Stewart.</p><p>"The winds are fairly quiet so far, and that's helping,'' she said.</p><p>One hundred firefighters, eight helicopters and 20 pieces of heavy equipment are battling the blaze.</p><p>Meanwhile, firefighters hoped to reach a 500-hectare forest fire in a remote area east of Invermere this morning. Fire officials believe lightning caused the blaze.</p><p>Tinder dry conditions in the province sparked fear of more fires this long weekend.</p><p>Campfire bans are in effect in the southern one-third of the province and in the Peace River region.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5XC1-N3J1-JDH1-C0KR-00000-00Forest fire inspires Smithers youth to join climate lawsuit2019-10-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:29ZLexisNexisNEWSForest fire inspires Smithers youth to join climate lawsuit

Montay Beaubein-Day is a 12-year-old Tahltan-Wet'suwet'en young person who attends school in Smithers.

He's also one of 15 youths taking Ottawa to court for failing to tackle climate change, and possibly robbing him and other young people of the same quality of life as generations before him have enjoyed.

"I wanted to get involved because in Telegraph [Creek] there was a huge fire and my family's ranch burnt down and I don't want that to happen to anybody else," he said.

He also pointed to a decline in fish stocks that he said is threatening his First Nations culture.

READ MORE: 15 Canadian youths to sue Ottawa for not acting on climate change

He said he wants to send a message to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

"I want Justin Trudeau to listen to the scientific experts on climate change," he said.

"I'm really proud of Montay," said Sarah Beaubein, his mother. "It's been something he's really wanted to do, and so, I knew it was going to take some commitment and he's up for it, so all we can do is support him in his journey."

Chad Day, Montay's father and president of the Tahltan Central Government, said the family is prepared for a process that could go on for years.

"The litigation is being funded by various sources, including the David Suzuki Foundation, so for the time being it's going to be a serious time commitment on behalf of Montay and our family, but we don't anticipate it is going to cost us any money at this time," he said.

The family was in the Lower Mainland Oct. 25 for a rally outside the Vancouver Art Gallery. Montay said it was an exciting experience with lots of people and energy.

The youth climate movement - which has picked up a lot of steam this year with the emergence of Greta Thunberg, the young Swedish activist - has also been marred by vitriolic backlash, particularly on social media.

Accusations of adult environmental organizations using children as pawns have become a staple of Facebook and Twitter commenters.

Even the President of the United States ridiculed Thunberg on Twitter.

A mural of Thunberg in Edmonton Alta. was defaced during her visit to that province last week.

READ MORE: Climate activist Greta Thunberg's mural defaced in Edmonton

Day said he is aware of the potential for the same kind of backlash to the lawsuit and his family is also prepared for that.

"I come from a legal background and I'm close to multiple of the lawyers involved in the background, so we will monitor that stuff closely and make sure that Montay doesn't do anything that he's uncomfortable with, but ultimately this was highly driven by Montay wanting to get involved," he said.

"Ultimately this is something the younger generation is really passionate about. Montay is the second youngest plaintiff of the 15, so although there's definitely going to be some pressure on him, we feel like there's not as much pressure on him at this particular point in time, but we are committed to him, if he's committed to stay involved in this in the long run."

Montay said he isn't worried about it.

Sierra Robinson, a 17-year-old Cowichan Valley teen who is leading the group of 15 said she wants to see politicians such as Trudeau pay more than lip-service to the issue.

"We're striking because of people like him, who are continuing to contribute to the climate crisis," Robinson said.

"It's terrifying because we can try to do everything we can on an individual level... but really, it's [up to] our politicians, as they're continuing to buy pipelines."

The lawsuit has two sides: one is the right to life, liberty and security of the person under section seven of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, while the other is more specific to the youths involved. That challenge will fall under section 15 of the Charter, and argue that young people are directly impacted by climate change in a way older generations are not.

The youths are asking the Supreme Court of Canada to create a science-based climate recovery plan, and stick to court-mandated targets so they can enjoy the same planet as generations before them.

Robinson knows suing the federal government is a drastic step. But it's one she feels she has to take to get the government's attention.

"We can't vote yet, so we're not included in these conversations that are shaping our futures," she said.

Robinson hopes the lawsuit will bring the issue of climate change closer to home for politicians.

"They live in these big fancy houses, or they live in a way where they're further away from the impacts," she said.

"I'm just frustrated that we have to go to the level of an entire lawsuit to get our government to take action. People should have done this a long time ago."

For Robinson, climate change hits a lot closer to home.

She remembers a neighbouring farmer whose well ran dry and had to choose between water for his cows, and watering his corn crop.

"He lost his whole crop of corn because he was only able to give that water to his cows to keep them alive," Robinson said.

"That's really scary."

VIDEO: Smithers students march down Main Street in support of global climate strike

The David Suzuki Foundation is hopeful the energy around climate change these days will push the courts to intervene.

"That's a very positive potential is that it will spur governments' attention and action on this issue, and make climate more of a priority," foundation CEO Stephen Cornish said.

Cornish said court action was necessary because the steps being taken by Ottawa are not good enough.

"What's important to note [is] that this isn't about a particular party," Cornish noted.

"There have been successive generations of government who have not lived up to this."

Cornish is hoping the lawsuit sets a precedent for other countries around the world.

Lawyer Chris Tollefson, who will make up part of the legal team, said the lawsuit will aim to set a precedent that Canadians do have the rights when it comes to what sort of planet they live on.

"There is a right to a stable climate [and] the government can provide that," Tollefson told Black Press Media by phone.

Tollefson said young people will live more of their lives affected by climate change.

"Because they're still growing physically, the impact of things like poor air quality, new kinds of diseases that are associated with climate change... those will impact them in a different way," he said.

A victory, Tollefson said, "can help us to restore a stable climate and keep the courts involved."

(CP) _ Hot, dry conditions this week following thunderstorms that swept across much of northwestern Ontario have raised the hazard of forest fires.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"The forest fire hazard is high and on the rise,'' said Travis Moffatt, Ministry of Natural Resources fire information officer for the west fire region.</p><p>Northwestern Ontario's first major fire of the season continued to spread rapidly Tuesday in a remote area northeast of Lake Nipigon.</p><p>The 35-square-kilometre blaze, 40 kilometres above the lake's northeastern tip, was too hot to fight with conventional ground crews.</p><p>Using helicopters, fire bosses set "back-burn'' fires around swamps and lakes from the air in an attempt to prevent the main fire from spreading.</p><p>"They're trying to get (the set) fires to burn into the main fire,'' Moffatt said.</p><p>While efforts to limit the fire continued, Buchanan Forest Products tried to save, by one estimate, up to 10,000 cords of logs intended for the company's two lumber mills in nearby Nakina and Longlac before they were consumed by the fire.</p><p>"We can't afford to lose one single stick of wood,'' said Buchanan spokesman Hartley Multamaki.</p><p>"They're loading it on trucks, trying to get it out of there as quickly as they can.''</p><p>Multamaki said if the 10,000 figure is accurate, it would represent 25,000 cubic metres of timber and a five-day supply at the mills.</p><p>As of early Tuesday evening, the fire was not threatening any communities, but residents in the Greenstone area occasionally smelled smoke, said Greenstone protective services manager Mike Hammer.</p><p>Moffatt said there were more than 24,000 lightning strikes across the region on Sunday.</p><p>On Monday, there were seven new fire starts, along with three that occurred over the weekend.</p><p>Four new small forest fires started Tuesday.</p><p>(Kenora Daily Miner and News)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Sullivan</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>TRURO, N.S.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Forest fires in Nova Scotia have burned hundreds of hectares of land this week -- as well as the home of a hermit who has been in seclusion for almost 50 years.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It looks like the end of the road," Willard MacDonald, known as the Gully Lake hermit, said yesterday as he gathered a few remnants of clothing from the charred remains of his hut.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The log-style abode in the Kemptown-Gully Lake area of north-central Nova Scotia was destroyed after a fire began in its flue Wednesday afternoon, said MacDonald.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>The fire quickly spread into the surrounding woods, eventually covering approximately 40 hectares of land before firefighters could knock it down.</p><p>Firefighters were still tackling hot spots yesterday.</p><p>Meanwhile, an out-of-control forest fire continued to burn in Nova Scotia's Shelburne County.</p><p>The blaze began earlier this week in the Tobeatic Wilderness Area and has spread to cover 800 hectares of land.</p><p>Bruce Carter of the Natural Resources Department said that fire was essentially burning in on itself, but added the situation could change with a shift in winds.</p><p>Ground crews planned to let the blaze burn, leaving the fight to aircraft, until at least Friday.</p><p>While the larger fire covered more ground, the human consequences were most visible as MacDonald tried to pick up what remained of his possessions -- a pair of woollen socks, an old coat, a sweater and a small pillow.</p><p>The hermit has lived alone in the Gully Lake area since the Second World War and said the loss of his home, along with his homemade guitar and his fiddle, was devastating.</p><p>"I never expected it, (but) everything is so dry," said the man believed to be in his late 80s.</p><p>A number of years ago, community concern for the hermit's welfare convinced the Department of Community Services to finance construction of a small cabin.</p><p>But after moving in for a brief period, MacDonald said that residence was simply too close to civilization for his liking.</p><p>"It's so busy, the road traffic noises," he said, "It bothers the concentration. I still do a little composing of music. It kind of interferes."</p><p>Moving back into the provincially built home was not an option MacDonald was keen to consider.</p><p>"The world is so … out there," he said, leaving his own definition unfinished.</p><p>"Is it true or what?" he asked, of such terrifying world events as the war in Iraq he had heard about through a small transistor radio that had also gone up in flames.</p><p>When asked about his age, MacDonald politely refused.</p><p>"I don't like to talk about age," he said, with the hint of a smile. "It makes me nervous. Doesn't it make you nervous?"</p><p>With that, clutching his belongings in his arms, MacDonald headed down the trail away from the remains of his home, swallowed up moments later by the forest.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Photo: Harry Sullivan, Truro Daily News; A forest fire destroyed the hut of Willard MacDonald yesterday. (CP) _ Strong winds and high temperatures are making work difficult for more than 150 firefighters now battling an out-of-control forest fire just east of Waterton Lakes National Park.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"We're hoping by the end of Thursday we'll be able to say it's being held, but this weather isn't helping,'' said Bernard Schmitte, commander of Alberta Sustainable Resources' fire response team, on Tuesday.</p><p>The fire, which started Sunday near the United States border just east of the Chief Mountain border crossing, has consumed about 1,900 hectares of thickly forested provincially owned land directly east of the national park boundary.</p><p>While it hasn't grown in size in the last two days, Schmitte said there are still large hot spots that continue to flare up and most of the area is smouldering as six helicopters drop buckets of water on the flames and bulldozers and ground crews work to create protective ditches around the perimeter of the blaze.</p><p>The fire was listed as 45 per cent contained as of Tuesday evening.</p><p>Ranchers living next to the land leased by the Pole Haven Community Grazing Association are on a short evacuation notice in case the fire spreads towards their homes.</p><p>"At this point, no private property is in danger but the residents are ready to leave early if they have to,'' Schmitte said.</p><p>(Calgary Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - The public shows little concern about forest fires, despite a massive blaze that singed the city's suburbs last year, Forest Ministry officals say.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The apathy is still there, that it won't happen to them,'' said Jim Mottishaw, a provincial fire prevention officer in Penticton.</p><p>"We're surprised that people haven't gotten concerned over it.''</p><p>The Garnet forest fire, which started a year ago today and grew to be one of the largest fires to threaten an urban area, demonstrated the danger of building homes in regions with a mix of housing and forests.</p><p>For years, fire and forestry officials have warned residents to take precautions: clear forest litter from roofs, create a fire-defence zone around buildings and burn potential fuel for fires when the forest fire risk is low.</p><p>Few people listen, said Mottishaw.</p><p>"I've done so many meetings, but it's still less than 30 per cent of the people who come out.''</p><p>Concern about the danger of forest fires was high immediately after the Garnet fire, but it gradually disappeared, said fire prevention officer Denis Gaudry.</p><p>"There's a time period right after, when people are aware, but people's defences go down.''</p><p>Developers have paid attention. They are creating esthetically pleasing fire break zones around new houses, for example.</p><p>"There's been a good push that way even though there's no legal requirement,'' Mottishaw said.</p><p>The Penticton Forest District deals with an average of 135 fires a year, although most can be controlled.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP-Staff) - Residents and officials in Timmins were breathing a sigh of relief last night after a forest fire that raged on the edge of town was brought under control.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The fire miraculously jumped over a couple of residences," said Inspector Ted O'Connor of Timmins police. "The flames were bearing down a trailer park, and for some reason, they diverted and changed direction, and sort of petered out.</p><p>"They have a few hotspots still, but they're keeping them contained right now."</p><p>The fire, burning just three kilometres from the heart of the city, was brought under control around 10 p.m. The ministry of natural resources crew were to resume fighting the blaze this morning.</p><p>"It was like a big mushroom cloud and it was crowning - jumping from treetop to treetop - so you almost see the flames from town," said Ben Legouffe, information officer for the Ministry of Natural Resources in Timmins. Firefighters from Sudbury were also to begin work in the morning.</p><p>One house on Baker Lake was damaged. No serious injuries have been reported.</p><p>Residents of three trailer parks along the Mattagami River were forced to evacuate soon after the fire broke out at 4:30 p.m. west of the city.</p><p>About 12 homes near Baker Lake, in the fire's path, were also evacuated.</p><p>Evacuees were taken to the McIntyre Community Building in Timmins and were to be moved to local hotels later.</p><p>"They're going to keep (the residents) out of the area just as a precaution," said one police officer.</p><p>Mayor Vic Power had declared a state of emergency.</p><p>Burning along a 200-hectare front, the fire jumped the 120-metre wide Mattagami River and forced the closing of Highway 101 West. The highway reopened last night.</p><p>Legouffe said the fire threatened to destroy several trailer parks and a built-up area containing homes and cottages.</p><p>Several water bombers were brought in to help control the flames and eight crews from local fire departments and ministry fire crews were on the ground.</p><p>Weather looked to be on the side of the firefighters. Rain was expected overnight.</p><p>"They are pretty upset and concerned," said Kathy Worman, branch manager for the Timmins and District Red Cross society. "The fire could destroy everything they own."</p><p>She said some people had managed to gather some belongings and valuables before they fled their homes.Ontario; forest; urn:contentItem:4ST3-TWY0-TX4V-K080-00000-00Province estimates bill for N.S. forest fire to run up to $800,0002008-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:29ZLexisNexisATLANTIC REGIONAL NEWSProvince estimates bill for N.S. forest fire to run up to $800,000CP

HALIFAX _ Nova Scotia's minister of natural resources said Thursday that he expects his department's costs to fight last weekend's forest fire east of Halifax could run up to $800,000.

David Morse said that estimate doesn't include the firefighting costs covered by the Halifax Regional Municipality.

More than 130 firefighters were on the ground near Porters Lake on Saturday in addition to the helicopters and water bombers called in by the Natural Resources Department.

''These big water bombers literally cost thousands of dollars every hour to have in the air,'' Morse said. ''At one point in time we actually had 13 aircraft in the air simultaneously.''

Morse said his department will foot the bill for the aircraft, including two water bombers called in from Newfoundland and Quebec.

He said borrowing the water bombers worked well and the province wouldn't save money by getting its own water bomber, which would cost about $28 million. The total doesn't include the costs of hiring pilots and maintaining the aircraft.

Morse said the province has similar borrowing agreements with several provinces and U.S. states, having called in aircraft 10 times over the past decade.

The minister said the province can ask the federal government for help with the costs if the bill totals over $1 million in the end.

However, Premier Rodney MacDonald said the province is prepared to foot the bill.

''We know that we're going to have to absorb the cost in emergency-type situations, and the government will be able to live within its means in doing so,'' MacDonald said.

Although there is a substantial amount of smoke no structures are at risk.</p><p>Fire information officer Dean Fenn says firefighters had a somewhat easier time on Tuesday when winds died down.</p><p>Crews are also making good progress on the Winnie Flats fire, about two kilometres from Merritt. The 150-hectare blaze was 90-per-cent contained yesterday afternoon.</p><p>A total of 633 fires have burned through B.C. forests this year, consuming 27,149 hectares.</p><p>Provincial fire information officer Rhada Fisher said hotter and drier weather is expected later this month.</p><p>To date, none of B.C.'s six fire regions have implemented campfire bans, although several have banned open burning and fireworks.</p><p>"We'll only put a campfire ban on when it's very necessary,'' Fisher said. The ferocious<br/>wall of flames has razed several homes and forced hundreds of<br/>people to flee several small communities. But the threat to the<br/>larger town of Slave Lake eased slightly with a shift in the winds.</p><p>CTV's Dan Kobe has our fire update.</p><p>DAN KOBE [Reporter]: Complete devastation. That's what Ron<br/>Giselbrecht returned home to. His four year old house gutted. A<br/>victim of the giant flames of the Chisholm inferno.</p><p>RON GISELBRECHT [Chisholm Resident]: What, am I not suppose to<br/>get anywhere in life anymore.</p><p>KOBE: Firefighters fought for days to save these homes. Many are<br/>now smoldering pits. About half the tiny town is gone. Crews are<br/>doing their best to protect the remaining houses. MUSKOKA - The Muskoka Fire Danger Rating is now set at moderate, according to Gravenhurst Fire Department in a Tweet at 12:13 p.m. on Tuesday, June 19.

The #Muskoka Forest Fire Danger Rating is now set at "Moderate" .

Daytime burning is still prohibited in our community - check @Gateway2Muskoka website for all other open air burning regulations please.@muskokafpo @Muskoka411 pic.twitter.com/5NWBAVUQ44 - GravenhurstFIRE (@GravenhurstFIRE) June 19, 2018

Daytime burning is still prohibited with a moderate rating. Carry out permitted fire activities with caution. For more information on what this means in your municipality, check local bylaws: Bracebridge, Gravenhurst, Huntsville, Muskoka Lakes, Lake of Bays, Georgian Bay. Call Toll Free 1-877-847-1577 for the up-to-date Muskoka Fire Danger Rating.

The Muskoka Fire Danger Rating is determined using the Fire Weather Index (FWI), an internationally used method for determining the risk of fires in open air. It uses factors such as the relative humidity, temperature, previous 24-hour rain amount, wind directions and wind speed in combination with the forest fuel type and loads to determine the risk of the forest to certain fire types. From this calculation the Forest Fire Danger Rating is made in consultation with the fire chiefs of the six area municipalities and the Ministry of Natural Resources.
